cardList.front: what does HTML stand for?
cardList.back: HyperText Markup Language

cardList.front: HTML is a programming language true or false?
cardList.back: false, it is just presentational. There is not logic or control structures

cardList.front: what is html used for?
cardList.back: to define the structure of the webpage

cardList.front: what are the building blocks of html?
cardList.back: tags (div, p, a, form, etc.)

cardList.front: what goes between html tags?
cardList.back: content

cardList.front: what is the outermost tag of a web page
cardList.back: <html> tag

cardList.front: what does the <!DOCTYPE> tag do? Is it an html tag?
cardList.back:
tells the browser what version of html the document is (html, html5, xhtml)

Doctype is not html

cardList.front: most of the time there are 2 children of an html tag, what tags are they?
cardList.back: head and body are the most common child tags of the html tag

cardList.front: what is the <head> tag used for?
cardList.back: The head of an HTML document is the part that is not displayed in the web browser when the page is loaded. It contains information such as the page <title>, links to CSS and JS, links to custom favicons, and other metadata (data about the HTML, such as the author, and important keywords that describe the document.)

cardList.front: what is the syntax for html comments?
cardList.back: <!-- comment -->

cardList.front: all html tags have one of two default dispaly values, what are they?
cardList.back: block  or inline

cardList.front: fill in the blank: ____ elements do not start a new line and fill in only the necessary space
cardList.back: inline

cardList.front: fill in the blank: ____ elements start a new line and take the full width available
cardList.back: block

cardList.front: name some of the more popular semantic html5 tags
cardList.back: header, footer, section, article, nav, details, aside

cardList.front: when should you load javscript in the <head> tag?
cardList.back: If the scripts contain some event-triggered functions or library

cardList.front: when should you load javscript in the <body> tag?
cardList.back: If the script writes the content on the page or is not inside a function then it should be placed inside the body section at the bottom

cardList.front: What is the difference between “display: none” and “visibility: hidden”
cardList.back: hen we use the attribute “visibility:hidden” for an HTML element then that element will be hidden from the webpage but still takes up space. Whereas, if we use the “display: none” attribute for an HTML element then the element will be hidden, and also it won’t take up any space on the webpage.

cardList.front: how does whitespace work in html tag content
cardList.back: No matter how much whitespace you use inside HTML element content (which can include one or more space character, but also line breaks), the HTML parser reduces each sequence of whitespace to a single space when rendering the code

cardList.front: how would you specify an html documents character encoding as utf-8?
cardList.back: <meta charset="utf-8">

cardList.front: what are the 2 most common attributes of <meta> tags?
cardList.back:
name, which specifies what type of information the tag contains
contenet, which contains the actual information

cardList.front: Ideally, what is the max number of h1 elements to use on a page
cardList.back: just one

cardList.front: what is an absolute URL
cardList.back: Points to a location defined by its absolute location on the web, including protocol and domain name.

cardList.front: what is an relative URL
cardList.back:
Points to a location that is relative to the file you are linking from

A relative URL will point to different places depending on the actual location of the file you refer from

cardList.front: what does CSS stand for?
cardList.back: cascading style sheets

cardList.front: true or false: is css a programming language?
cardList.back: false

cardList.front: what is css used for?
cardList.back: web page layout and design (used in conjunction with html which simply provides stucture)

cardList.front: what are the three ways to style html elements with css?
cardList.back:
inline: directly in the html
internal: within  <style> tags
external: with <link> tags that reference an external style sheet

cardList.front: describe the box model from inside out
cardList.back: content > padding > border > margin

cardList.front: what is a pseudo class?
cardList.back: A pseudo-class is a selector that selects elements that are in a specific state, e.g. they are the first element of their type, or they are being hovered over by the mouse pointer. They tend to act as if you had applied a class to some part of your document, often helping you cut down on excess classes in your markup, and giving you more flexible, maintainable code.

cardList.front: what is a pseudo element?
cardList.back: Pseudo-elements behave in a similar way, however they act as if you had added a whole new HTML element into the markup, rather than applying a class to existing element

cardList.front: how does pseudo-class and pseudo-element sytnax differ?
cardList.back: pseudo class = a single colon, pseudo element = double colon (: vs ::)

cardList.front: write a css selector to select only text inputs
what is the difference between box-sizing: content-box; and box-sizing: border-bod
cardList.back: content-box is the default value for box-sizing. it calculates an elements dimensions by content (width, height) without factoring in, padding, border, and margin. border-box calculates width by factoring in content, padding, and border, but not margin

cardList.front: describe position: static
cardList.back: element will be positioned as it appears in the html document

cardList.front: describe position: relative
cardList.back: element will be positioned in relation to its defautl ( static)  positioning

cardList.front: describe position: absolute
cardList.back: is positioned relative to the nearest positioned ancestor, if there are no positioned elements, it will be positioned of the body

cardList.front: describe position: fixed
cardList.back: element is fixed in viewport and wont leave the viewport when scrolling

cardList.front: describe position: initial
cardList.back: sets the position back to the default setting

cardList.front: describe position: inherit
cardList.back: inherits position from parent

cardList.front: a css ___ selector applies rules by targeting tag names
cardList.back: element

cardList.front: a css ___ selector applies rules by targeting element with a specific id
cardList.back: id

cardList.front: a css ___ selector applies rules to all elements, what is its syntax
cardList.back: universal, asterisk

cardList.front: a css ___ selector applies rules by targeting element with a specific class
cardList.back: class

cardList.front: The CSS ___ selector matches elements based on the presence or value of a given attribute.
cardList.back: attribute

cardList.front: A CSS ___ is a keyword added to a selector that specifies a special state of the selected element(s)
cardList.back: pseudo-class

cardList.front: A CSS ___ is a keyword added to a selector that lets you style a specific part of the selected element(s).
cardList.back: pseudo-element

cardList.front: The ___ — typically represented by a single space ( ) character — combines two selectors such that elements matched by the second selector are selected if they have an ancestor (parent, parent's parent, parent's parent's parent, etc) element matching the first selector.
cardList.back: descendant combinator

cardList.front: The ___ (>) is placed between two CSS selectors. It matches only those elements matched by the second selector that are the direct children of elements matched by the first.
cardList.back: child combinator

cardList.front: The ___ (+) separates two selectors and matches the second element only if it immediately follows the first element, and both are children of the same parent element.
cardList.back: adjacent sibling combinator

cardList.front: The ___ (~) separates two selectors and matches all iterations of the second element, that are following the first element (though not necessarily immediately), and are children of the same parent element.
cardList.back: general sibling combinator

cardList.front: what are user agent styles?
cardList.back: the browser's (user agent) default style rules

cardList.front: arrange the following selector types in order of specificity, least to greatest: class, type, id
cardList.back: type, class, id

cardList.front: if two style rules with the same specificity are contained in a stylesheet, which is applied?
cardList.back: as per the cascade rule, the one that occurs later in the style sheet

cardList.front: define specificity:
cardList.back: Specificity is how the browser decides which rule applies if multiple rules have different selectors, but could still apply to the same element. It is basically a measure of how specific a selector's selection will be

cardList.front: what style rules count towards thousands in a specificity calculation?
cardList.back: inline styles with the style attribute

cardList.front: what style rules count towards hundreds in a specificity calculation?
cardList.back: id selectors

cardList.front: what style rules count towards tens in a specificity calculation?
cardList.back: class selectors, attribute selectors, or pseudo-classes

cardList.front: what style rules count towards ones in a specificity calculation?
cardList.back: element selector or pseudo-element

cardList.front: how do you override specificity calculations and force styles on element(s)
cardList.back: the !important keyword

cardList.front: what are the outer display types
cardList.back: inline and block

cardList.front: what are the inner display types
cardList.back: flex and grid

cardList.front: say two block level elements have a margin of 50px and 30px respectively, how much space will be between the 2 elements? 80px or 50px? why?
cardList.back: 50px, since the larger of the 2 margins is what gets dispalyed, they aren't combined

cardList.front: which part of the box model can have negative values?
cardList.back: margin

cardList.front: applying margin padding and border to inline elements will cause other boxes to be pushed away from the element, true or false?
cardList.back: false

cardList.front: applying margin padding and border to inline-block elements will cause other boxes to be pushed away from the element, true or false?
cardList.back: true

cardList.front: describe overflow
cardList.back: verflow happens when there is too much content to fit in a box

cardList.front: what are the vw and vh units equivalent to
cardList.back: vw is 1% of the viewport's width, vh is 1% of the viewport's height

cardList.front: what is the em unit equivalent to ?
cardList.back: the parent element's font size

cardList.front: what is the em unit equivalent to ?
cardList.back: the root element's font size

cardList.front: What's the difference between undefined and not defined in JavaScript?
cardList.back:
A variable can be declared but not defined. When we try to access it, It will output as undefined

'not defined' occurs when a variable is referenced that doesnt exist

cardList.front: What is the drawback of declaring methods directly in JavaScript objects?
cardList.back: it is not efficient in terms of memory usage. It is better to add the method to the object's prototype. that way the method isnt copied on each instance and is created only once

cardList.front: What is “closure” in javascript?
cardList.back:
A closure is a function defined inside another function (called parent function) and as such it has access to the variables declared and defined within its parent function's scope.

The closure has access to the variables in three scopes:

Variable declared in his own scope
Variable declared in its parent function's scope
Variable declared in the global namespace

cardList.front: Write a mul function which will work properly when invoked with following syntax; mul(x)(y)(z)
cardList.back: const mul = function(x) { return function(y) { return(z) { return x* y * z; } } }

cardList.front: what does Array.splice() do?
cardList.back: method changes the contents of an array by removing or replacing existing elements and/or adding new elements in place

cardList.front: describe the parameters of array.splice()
cardList.back:
start: the index at which to start changing the array. if > or = to array.length the index will be set to array.length

deleteCount: (optional) An integer indicating the number of elements in the array to remove from start

item1, item2, ... : (optional) items to add to the array at start.

cardList.front: what happens when you visit a website in your browser?
cardList.back:
The browser goes to the DNS server, and finds the real address of the server that the website lives on.

The browser sends an HTTP request message to the server, asking it to send a copy of the website to the client. This message, and all other data sent between the client and the server, is sent across your internet connection using TCP/IP.

If the server approves the client's request, the server sends the client a "200 OK" message, which means "Of course you can look at that website! Here it is", and then starts sending the website's files to the browser as a series of small chunks called data packets.

The browser assembles the small chunks into a complete web page and displays it to you.

cardList.front: in what order do the webpage files returned from the servet get parsed?
cardList.back: html, css, then js

cardList.front: what are packets?
cardList.back: Packets are  the format in which the data is sent from server to client. What do we mean here? Basically, when data is sent across the web, it is sent as thousands of small chunks, so that many different web users can download the same website at the same time.

cardList.front: what is http?
cardList.back: Hypertext Transfer Protocol, or HTTP, is a messaging protocol that allows web browsers to communicate with web servers (where web sites are stored).

cardList.front: what is graceful degradation?
cardList.back: writing code so that it falls back to a simpler but still usable experience in older browsers

cardList.front: what is the html5 equivalent of an img tag?
cardList.back: <figure>, which wraps the img tag and allows for <figcaption> tags in place of a title attribute on the img

cardList.front: aside from video and audio tags, what are the other html tags used to embed content
cardList.back: <iframe> (other web pages), <embed>, and <object> (pdfs, svgs, and

cardList.front: what attribute should you always use with an iframe to prevent security vulnerabilities
cardList.back: sandbox

cardList.front: what is SVG?
cardList.back: SVG is an XML-based language for describing vector images. It's basically markup, like HTML, except that you've got many different elements for defining the shapes you want to appear in your image, and the effects you want to apply to those shapes

cardList.front: what is art direction?
cardList.back: The problem whereby you want to serve cropped images for different layouts — for example a landscape image showing a full scene for a desktop layout, and a portrait image showing the main subject zoomed in for a mobile layout. You can solve this problem using the <picture> element.

cardList.front: what is resolution switching?
cardList.back: The problem whereby you want to serve smaller image files to narrow screen devices, as they don't need huge images like desktop displays do — and also optionally that you want to serve different resolution images to high density/low density screens. You can solve this problem by using vector graphics (SVG images) and the srcset with sizes attributes.
